questions.text: A 54-year-old Lady with breast lump of size 6 x 7 cm, with skin ulceration and small area of inflammation over skin of breast belongs to what TNM stage?
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) T4b

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ In breast cancer staging , T4b is assigned for tumors with skin involvement such as ulceration or localized inflammation, while T4d is for generalized skin changes indicative of inflammatory breast cancer.
  • ➤ breast cancer staging
  • ➤ T4b
  • ➤ T4d

questions.text: Identify the complication following lateral and pelvic dissection due to injury to Nervi Erigentes during abdominoperineal resection for rectal carcinoma?

options.label: A
options.text: Parasympathetic - bladder dysfunction and retrograde ejaculation

options.label: C
options.text: Sympathetic - retrograde ejaculation and bladder dysfunction

questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Parasympathetic -bladder dysfunction and impotence.

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Injury to the Nervi Erigentes (pelvic splanchnic nerves) during pelvic dissection primarily affects the parasympathetic system , leading to complications such as bladder dysfunction and impotence .
  • ➤ Injury to the Nervi Erigentes (pelvic splanchnic nerves)
  • ➤ parasympathetic system
  • ➤ bladder dysfunction and impotence

questions.text: Which of the following manifestations is not typically associated with multiple endocrine neoplasia type 1 syndrome?
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Pheochromocytoma

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ In MEN1 syndrome , the characteristic features are parathyroid hyperplasia, pancreatic endocrine tumors, and pituitary tumors . Pheochromocytoma is not part of MEN1 and is instead associated with MEN2 .
  • ➤ MEN1 syndrome
  • ➤ parathyroid hyperplasia, pancreatic endocrine tumors, and pituitary tumors
  • ➤ Pheochromocytoma
  • ➤ MEN2
  • ➤ Pheochromocytoma and medullary thyroid cancer is seen in MEN 2.

questions.text: A 50-year-old Type 2 diabetic patient presents with fever and hypotension to the casualty. He gives a history of a boil in the perianal area which developed 2 weeks ago. On examination, the perianal area is as shown in the picture below. Identify the incorrect statement about this condition:

options.label: A
options.text: It is caused by multiple organisms

options.label: C
options.text: Surgical treatment is required in most cases

questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Mortality is low

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Fournier's gangrene is a rapidly progressing, polymicrobial infection with a high mortality rate . It requires urgent surgical debridement IV antibiotics, especially in immunocompromised patients, such as diabetics.
  • ➤ Fournier's gangrene
  • ➤ high mortality rate
  • ➤ Mortality is 50%.
  • ➤ Mortality is 50%.

questions.text: 50-year-old male presented with head trauma during cricket. He had transient loss of consciousness but is currently lucid. CT brain shows the following. The next step is:
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Observe

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ In cases of mild traumatic brain injury with a normal CT scan and no signs of deterioration, observation is the best course of action.Bottom of Form
  • ➤ mild traumatic brain injury
  • ➤ observation

questions.text: What could be the possible diagnosis of a 35-year-old male patient with a history of hypertension and a palpable flank lump, and whose ultrasound abdomen is shown below?
questions.correct_answer: B. Autosomal dominant polycystic kidney disease
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Autosomal dominant polycystic kidney disease

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ ADPKD typically presents in adults with hypertension, enlarged cystic kidneys, and sometimes flank pain . The condition is distinct from ARPKD , which presents in in 30-50 year age group and from RCC , which usually involves a single tumor rather than widespread cysts.
  • ➤ ADPKD
  • ➤ hypertension, enlarged cystic kidneys, and sometimes flank pain
  • ➤ ARPKD
  • ➤ RCC

questions.text: A 50-year-old female has recently undergone total thyroidectomy for a thyroid mass. The histopathological examination is shown as below. Which of these is incorrect?

options.label: A
options.text: Radioiodine scan is done after surgery

options.label: B
options.text: It is the most common primary thyroid malignancy in areas of iodine sufficiency

options.label: D
options.text: Cervical LN metastasis to level 6 group is common

questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Prognosis is poor

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Papillary thyroid carcinoma (PTC) is the most common thyroid malignancy in iodine-sufficient areas, has a good prognosis, and commonly spreads to the central (level 6) lymph nodes . Post-surgical management includes radioiodine scanning for residual disease detection.
  • ➤ Papillary thyroid carcinoma (PTC)
  • ➤ central (level 6) lymph nodes
  • ➤ radioiodine scanning
  • ➤ Common etiology - Radiation exposure, family history of thyroid malignancies, genetic abnormalities in either the RET gene or the BRAF gene. Clinical presentation - asymptomatic thyroid swelling with cervical lymph node enlargement. In advanced disease there may be compression by the thyroid mass causing features like hoarseness, dysphagia, cough, or dyspnea.
  • ➤ Common etiology - Radiation exposure, family history of thyroid malignancies, genetic abnormalities in either the RET gene or the BRAF gene.
  • ➤ Clinical presentation - asymptomatic thyroid swelling with cervical lymph node enlargement. In advanced disease there may be compression by the thyroid mass causing features like hoarseness, dysphagia, cough, or dyspnea.

questions.text: Identify the role of the device.

options.label: C
options.text: Optical trocar for entry in laparoscopy

questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Closed technique of pneumoperitoneum

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The Veress needle is used to create a closed pneumoperitoneum by insufflating CO₂, allowing safe entry into the abdomen during laparoscopic procedures. It is preferred due to the reduced risk of air embolism and its non-combustible nature.
  • ➤ Veress needle
  • ➤ closed pneumoperitoneum

questions.text: A 54-year-old woman underwent surgery for breast carcinoma 10 years back. She now presents with painless swelling involving her arm, which started 2 weeks ago. Upon examination, the affected arm appears swollen and feels heavy, with visible thickening and nodularity of the skin. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Lymphangiosarcoma

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Lymphangiosarcoma (Stewart-Treves syndrome) should be suspected in patients with long-standing lymphedema and the development of nodular or thickened skin. This is a malignancy that requires prompt diagnosis and management.
  • ➤ Lymphangiosarcoma (Stewart-Treves syndrome)

questions.text: A 4-year-old child was playing at home. Suddenly his mother found him lying on the floor choking. She suspects he has ingested a foreign body and rushes him to the casualty. An Xray is done which shows the following picture. What is the next line of management?
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Immediate Endoscopic removal

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ In cases of foreign body ingestion, determine the location via X-ray. Endoscopic removal is indicated for esophageal foreign bodies , especially for batteries, to prevent serious complications. The Heimlich maneuver is used for immediate airway obstruction, not for esophageal foreign bodies.
  • ➤ Endoscopic removal is indicated for esophageal foreign bodies
  • ➤ Heimlich maneuver

questions.text: A fair skinned female patient after laparotomy, developed an elevated scar which showed minimal itching and appearance as shown. What is the diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Hypertrophic scar

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Hypertrophic scars often develop on areas of skin tension, such as surgical incisions, and usually improve over time. Keloids are more common in darker skin, tend to extend beyond the original wound, and are persistent.
  • ➤ Hypertrophic scars
  • ➤ Keloids
  • ➤ KELOID
  • ➤ VS
  • ➤ HYPERTROPHIC SCAR

questions.text: A patient presents with acute abdominal pain after alcohol binge. The given finding is seen. What test is diagnostic of the given condition?
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Serum lipase

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ For a patient presenting with abdominal pain and clinical signs suggestive of pancreatitis (e.g., Grey Turner’s sign), serum lipase is the primary diagnostic test, while CT abdomen is reserved for assessing complications or the severity of pancreatitis.
  • ➤ serum lipase
  • ➤ CT abdomen

questions.text: Which of these is incorrect about Child Pugh score?

options.label: A
options.text: Assesses severity of chronic liver disease

options.label: B
options.text: Includes serum albumin, bilirubin and creatinine levels

options.label: D
options.text: Each component is scored from 1 to 3 with maximum of 15 points.

questions.correct_answer: B. Includes serum albumin, bilirubin and creatinine levels
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Includes serum albumin, bilirubin and creatinine levels

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The Child-Pugh score assesses the severity of chronic liver disease using serum bilirubin, serum albumin, prothrombin time/INR, ascites, and encephalopathy, not creatinine, with higher scores indicating worse prognosis.
  • ➤ Child-Pugh score

questions.text: All of these are causes of vomiting in a neonate at birth except?
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Infantile pyloric stenosis

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Infantile pyloric stenosis does not present with vomiting immediately at birth but usually develops later in infancy (typically around 3-6 weeks of age), distinguishing it from other causes of neonatal vomiting such as duodenal atresia, jejunal atresia, and meconium ileus.

questions.text: A 50-year-old woman had an abdominal hysterectomy two years ago and is now experiencing abdominal pain, vomiting bile, and high-pitched bowel sounds during examination. The presence of multiple air-fluid levels, along with air within the biliary tree is seen on imaging. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Gallstone ileus

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Gallstone ileus is characterized by pneumobilia, small bowel obstruction, and a history of gallstone disease, making it distinguishable from other forms of bowel obstruction, including those due to adhesions or hernias.

questions.text: In congenital hypertrophic pyloric stenosis (CHPS) which of these would not be true?

options.label: B
options.text: Visible peristalsis is seen on giving a test feed

options.label: C
options.text: Common metabolic condition seen is Hypokalemic alkalosis

questions.correct_answer: D. Fluid of choice is RL
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Fluid of choice is RL

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ In congenital hypertrophic pyloric stenosis (CHPS), the appropriate fluid management involves Dextrose Normal Saline (DNS) with added potassium chloride (KCl) to correct hypokalemia, rather than Ringer's Lactate (RL).

questions.text: Identify the scenario in which the technique is performed:
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Liver resection

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Pringle maneuver is used to control bleeding by clamping the hepatic artery and portal vein within the hepatoduodenal ligament during liver surgeries or liver trauma .
  • ➤ Pringle maneuver
  • ➤ control bleeding by clamping the hepatic artery and portal vein within the hepatoduodenal ligament during liver surgeries or liver trauma

questions.text: Masaoka staging is used in?
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Thymoma

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The Masaoka staging system is uniquely used to classify thymomas based on the extent of local and distant invasion, guiding treatment and prognostic decisions for thymic tumors.
  • ➤ Masaoka: Thymoma Barcelona clinic: Hepatoma Ann-Arbor: Lymphoma
  • ➤ Masaoka: Thymoma
  • ➤ Barcelona clinic: Hepatoma
  • ➤ Ann-Arbor: Lymphoma

questions.text: All of these are indications of performing 24 hr pH study in patients of GERD except?
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Presence of hiatus hernia

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ A 24-hour pH study is indicated in cases of GERD with atypical symptoms, recurrence despite PPI therapy, or when planning anti-reflux surgery, but it is not used to diagnose hiatus hernia, which requires imaging studies for assessment.
  • ➤ Ambulatory pH recording (with or without impedance measurement) are justified to establish the diagnosis and guide management: In patients with atypical symptoms (Extra-esophageal symptoms may include chronic cough, laryngitis, asthma, and dental erosions especially on the lingual and palatal tooth surfaces) Persistent symptoms despite PPI therapy In patients considered for surgery, it is also prudent to have objective proof of significant reflux
  • ➤ Ambulatory pH recording (with or without impedance measurement) are justified to establish the diagnosis and guide management:
  • ➤ In patients with atypical symptoms (Extra-esophageal symptoms may include chronic cough, laryngitis, asthma, and dental erosions especially on the lingual and palatal tooth surfaces)
  • ➤ Persistent symptoms despite PPI therapy
  • ➤ In patients considered for surgery, it is also prudent to have objective proof of significant reflux

questions.text: An adult male is presented with duodenal ulcer is offered various surgical options for its treatment. Which of the surgical options listed below causes least complications?
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Highly selective vagotomy

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Highly selective vagotomy is the preferred surgical option for duodenal ulcer treatment when minimizing complications is a priority. It targets only the acid-producing areas, preserving gastric motility and resulting in fewer post-operative complications.

questions.text: Which of these is not a risk factor for cholangiocarcinoma?
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Acute viral hepatitis

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Cholangiocarcinoma risk is associated with chronic conditions causing long-term bile duct irritation, whereas acute viral hepatitis does not contribute to its development.

questions.text: Identify the type of drain:
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Closed suction

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Closed suction drains, like the Romovac or JP drain, are used to evacuate fluid from surgical sites while maintaining a sterile, closed system, which minimizes infection risk and allows better monitoring of drainage.

questions.text: A patient presents with painless PR bleed during defecation. The following is seen on proctoscopy. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Hemorrhoids

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Hemorrhoids are characterized by painless rectal bleeding during defecation and appear as smooth, vascular protrusions on proctoscopy, distinguishing them from other anorectal conditions.
  • ➤ Grade 1 or 2 are managed by sclerotherapy/banding Grade 3 or 4 are managed by stapled procedures (image) or hemorrhoidectomy (Milligan Morgan)
  • ➤ Grade 1 or 2 are managed by sclerotherapy/banding
  • ➤ Grade 3 or 4 are managed by stapled procedures (image) or hemorrhoidectomy (Milligan Morgan)

questions.text: A chronic smoker gets cramping pain in his calf after walking about 500 m. What is the likely pathology?
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Superficial femoral arterial block

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Calf pain during walking, particularly in a chronic smoker, is indicative of intermittent claudication, with the most common cause being a blockage in the superficial femoral artery.
  • ➤ Sites of Obstruction

questions.text: Which of the options below is an acceptable condition for breast conservative surgery?

options.label: A
options.text: Small sized tumor but N1 axillary metastasis

options.label: B
options.text: Tumor size exceeding the size of the breast

questions.correct_answer: A. Small sized tumor but N1 axillary metastasis
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Small sized tumor but N1 axillary metastasis

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Breast conservative surgery can be performed in patients with small tumors and N1 axillary disease, as long as proper axillary clearance and radiotherapy can be administered.

questions.text: A 45-year-old male who has been on treatment for varicose veins for the past 4 years, presents with eczema over the limb. What C stage does he belong to?
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) C4a

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ In the CEAP classification, C4a includes skin changes such as eczema and pigmentation related to venous disease, while more advanced skin changes like lipodermatosclerosis are categorized under C4b.
  • ➤ CEAP CLASSIFICATION
  • ➤ CEAP CLASSIFICATION
  • ➤ C1-Telang/RV C2- VV C3- edema C4a- pigment/eczema 4b- LDS/Atrophie blanche 4c- corona phlebectasia C5- healed ulcer C6- active ulcer
  • ➤ C1-Telang/RV
  • ➤ C2- VV
  • ➤ C3- edema
  • ➤ C4a- pigment/eczema 4b- LDS/Atrophie blanche 4c- corona phlebectasia
  • ➤ 4b- LDS/Atrophie blanche 4c- corona phlebectasia
  • ➤ 4b- LDS/Atrophie blanche
  • ➤ 4c- corona phlebectasia
  • ➤ C5- healed ulcer
  • ➤ C6- active ulcer
  • ➤ A-Asymtomatic
  • ➤ S- Symptomatic
  • ➤ R- Recurrent

questions.text: A young patient suffered from Blunt trauma to the abdomen and was brought to the Emergency room. He is unstable with a blood pressure of 90/60 mm of Hg. You are the doctor, basic resuscitation is done with Intravenous fluids, FAST is positive. He is not improving despite Intravenous fluids. The next step is?
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Exploratory Laparotomy

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ In cases of blunt abdominal trauma with an unstable patient and positive FAST, immediate exploratory laparotomy is the next step to manage internal bleeding or severe injuries.

questions.text: Which of the following statements is correct about triage?
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Yellow: urgent care needed

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ In the triage system, "Yellow" signifies patients who need urgent care but are not in immediate life-threatening situations, while "Red" is for immediate life-saving intervention, "Black" indicates moribund or deceased, and "Green" denotes ambulatory patients with minor injuries.

questions.text: A 45-year-old male came with a history of progressive dysphagia, initially to solid foods and now to liquids too. He has also experienced significant weight loss over the past few months. Which of the following is the investigation of choice for diagnosing the underlying cause of his symptoms?
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Upper GI endoscopy

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ In cases of progressive dysphagia with weight loss, upper GI endoscopy with biopsy is the investigation of choice for diagnosing possible esophageal cancer.

questions.text: A road traffic accident patient is confused, opens his eyes on painful stimuli, flexes one limb on painful stimuli, and can localize the stimulus with the other limb. His Glasgow Coma Score is?
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) 11

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The Glasgow Coma Score for a patient is calculated by assessing eye opening, verbal, and motor responses, and the highest motor response score is taken when there is variability.
  • ➤ Eye opening on pain: E2 Confused: V4 Localising pain: M5
  • ➤ Eye opening on pain: E2
  • ➤ Confused: V4
  • ➤ Localising pain: M5

questions.text: Identify the incorrect statement pathology in the image.

options.label: A
options.text: The pathology is commonly seen in dog

options.label: B
options.text: The commonly affected organs are liver followed by lung

options.label: C
options.text: Excision is reserved for cases where other measures fail

questions.correct_answer: A. The pathology is commonly seen in dog
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) The pathology is commonly seen in dog

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Hydatid disease is primarily seen in sheep, with dogs acting as definitive hosts for the parasite. Humans may develop hydatid cysts, commonly affecting the liver and lung, and cyst rupture can lead to anaphylaxis.

questions.text: Which of the following is not a risk factor for squamous cell carcinoma of esophagus?
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Baretts esophagus

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Barrett's esophagus is a risk factor for adenocarcinoma of the esophagus, while squamous cell carcinoma is more commonly associated with factors like tobacco, alcohol, and corrosive injury.

questions.text: A child is born with a neck swelling as shown. The swelling shows brilliant transillumination. This is likely to be a?
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Cystic hygroma

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Cystic hygroma is a congenital lymphatic malformation, often present at birth, which shows brilliant transillumination due to its fluid content. It is commonly located in the posterior triangle of the neck.

questions.text: What is the preferred treatment for a tumor of the superficial lobe of the parotid gland showing adenomatous and myxoid elements as shown?
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Superficial parotidectomy

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Superficial parotidectomy is the treatment of choice for pleomorphic adenoma of the parotid gland to prevent recurrence and potential malignant transformation.

questions.text: What should be the next step in a patient who presented in the emergency with respiratory distress, dilated neck veins and hyper-resonance on percussion?

options.label: A
options.text: Wide bore needle insertion in 5th intercostal space

questions.correct_answer: A. Wide bore needle insertion in 5th intercostal space
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Wide bore needle insertion in 5th intercostal space

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ In cases of suspected tension pneumothorax, immediate needle decompression is the first step, followed by imaging to confirm diagnosis and an ICD for definitive management.

questions.text: In a patient at risk of re-feeding syndrome, which of the following electrolyte imbalances is typically not associated with this condition?
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Hypermagnesemia

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Re-feeding syndrome is associated with hypokalemia, hypomagnesemia, and hypophosphatemia, with hypophosphatemia being the most consistent abnormality. Hypermagnesemia is not typically seen in this condition.

questions.text: A patient presents to the emergency room with a history of a road traffic accident. On examination, the patient is found to have shock and hypotension. Extended focused assessment with sonography for trauma (eFAST) is negative. X-ray is normal, and ECG shows no abnormalities. The SpO2 is 93%, and the blood pressure is 80/60 mmHg with a pulse rate of 60/min. What type shock is most likely present?
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Neurogenic shock

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Neurogenic shock, typically resulting from spinal cord injury, presents with hypotension and bradycardia due to loss of sympathetic tone, differentiating it from other types of shock that involve compensatory tachycardia.

questions.text: In a seat belt injury, which of the following organs is most commonly affected?
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Mesentery

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ In seat belt injuries, the mesentery of the small bowel is the most commonly affected structure, followed by hollow viscera if mesenteric injury is not an option.

questions.text: A patient has undergone cholecystectomy few days back and now the patient has presented with upper Abdominal pain. MRCP was done which showed leak of bile from the cystic duct stump. Patient is hemodynamically stable. Which of the following should be the next line of management?
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) ERCP and stenting

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ In hemodynamically stable patients with a cystic duct stump bile leak post-cholecystectomy (Strasberg type A), ERCP with stenting is the preferred management to facilitate healing and prevent further complications.

questions.text: A 10 year old boy presented to the surgery OPD . On examination, his left scrotal sac is empty and under-developed. On clinical examination the left testis was found in the superficial inguinal pouch. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Left ectopic testis

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ An ectopic testis deviates from the normal path of descent and that the superficial inguinal pouch is the most common ectopic location. This is distinct from undescended or retractile testes, which follow different patterns of abnormal testicular position.
  • ➤ An ectopic testis deviates from the normal path of descent

questions.text: A 52-year-old patient with a history of chronic alcohol abuse presents to the clinic with complaints of lesion in the mouth. A picture of the patient's oral cavity is provided, which reveals several white patches on the tongue and inner cheek which cant be rubbed off. Based on this presentation, what is the likely diagnosis and next step for this patient?
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Leukoplakia-biopsy

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Leukoplakia presents as a non-removable white patches or plaques that develop on the mucous membranes of the mouth, throat, or other areas of the body, often in patients with risk factors such as alcohol or tobacco use. It requires a biopsy, typically from the lesion's border, to rule out dysplasia or malignancy.
  • ➤ Leukoplakia presents as a non-removable

questions.text: In Modified Radical Neck Dissection (MRND), which of the following structures is not preserved?
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Submandibular gland

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ In Modified Radical Neck Dissection (MRND), the submandibular gland is typically removed, while the sternocleidomastoid muscle, internal jugular vein, and spinal accessory nerve are preserved to minimize functional impairment.

questions.text: Which of the following is true regarding Crohn's disease?

options.label: C
options.text: Crohn's disease most commonly involves the perianal region

options.label: D
options.text: Superficial ulcers observed are diagnostic of Crohn's disease

questions.correct_answer: B. Creeping mesenteric fat is seen
questions.explanation:
Ans.

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Creeping mesenteric fat is a distinctive feature of Crohn's disease, which also presents with skip lesions and deep, transmural ulcers.

questions.text: Heller's operation is often combined with:
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Fundoplication

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Heller's myotomy for achalasia is often combined with a partial fundoplication (Dor or Toupet) to reduce the risk of GERD post-surgery.

questions.text: A 45-year female with history of migraine was taking regular NSAIDs. She experienced sudden onset abdominal pain with vomiting. Examination revealed generalized tenderness. X ray is as shown. Next step?
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Take up for surgery

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ In cases of acute abdomen with pneumoperitoneum confirmed by X-ray, immediate surgery is indicated to manage perforation. CT is only necessary if the X-ray findings are inconclusive.

questions.text: A 35-year-old man in an inebriated state fell in the bathroom and was taken to the casualty. He complained of intense pain in the suprapubic region. On examination, abdominal distention was present with generalized rigidity. No blood was seen at urethral meatus. Heart rate and blood pressure was normal. What is the diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Intraperitoneal bladder rupture

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Intraperitoneal bladder rupture is suspected when there is abdominal rigidity, distention, and signs of peritonitis following trauma, especially in cases of a full bladder and no signs of urethral injury.

questions.text: A 56-year-old male has been recently diagnosed with renal cell carcinoma. The imaging studies reveal that the tumor is less than 4 cm in size. Based on this information, what would be the most appropriate initial treatment approach for this patient's condition?
questions.explanation:
Ans.

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ For T1a renal cell carcinoma (≤4 cm), partial nephrectomy is the preferred treatment to remove the tumor while preserving kidney function. RCC is resistant to both chemotherapy and radiotherapy.

questions.text: A patient present with herniation of intestinal loop which passes along the spermatic cord and reaches till scrotum/cremaster muscle. What is the pathology?
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Indirect inguinal hernia

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ An indirect inguinal hernia follows the inguinal canal and can extend into the scrotum alongside the spermatic cord, unlike direct inguinal or femoral hernias.

questions.text: 8-year-old boy presents with right sided acute scrotum. Examination reveals tenderness which worsens on lifting the testis. Which of these is the likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Testicular torsion

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ In cases of acute scrotum with tenderness that worsens upon testis elevation, testicular torsion should be suspected, necessitating urgent intervention to prevent irreversible damage.

questions.text: A 55-year-old male presents with complaints of pain in the calf muscles after walking for a certain distance. The pain is relieved by rest and reoccurs upon resuming walking. Based on Boyd’s classification, what is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Grade III

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Boyd’s classification for intermittent claudication includes only three grades, with Grade III representing pain that becomes unbearable on walking, relieved by rest.

questions.text: A teenage patient came with pain in RIF since 5 days and a palpable lump. He is currently afebrile and pulse is 90/minute. Blood investigation shows increased TLC. A diagnosis of phlegmonous appendicitis is suspected. What is the next step?
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Conservative management

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ For phlegmonous appendicitis with an appendicular lump, conservative management (Ochsner-Sherren regimen) is the preferred approach, followed by an interval appendectomy after 4-6 weeks. Immediate surgery is avoided to prevent complications.

questions.text: Which of these is not a common complication of ERCP?
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Small bowel obstruction

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The most common complication of ERCP is pancreatitis. Other potential complications include hemorrhage and duodenal perforation, but small bowel obstruction is not associated with ERCP.

questions.text: A 28-year-old pregnant woman presents with a history of decreased fetal movements and respiratory distress is observed in her newborn. On examination, the neonate appears cyanotic with increased work of breathing. Auscultation reveals bowel sounds in the left hemithorax. Chest x-ray showed multiple air fluid levels in left thorax. Which of the following congenital anomalies is most likely responsible for these findings?
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Congenital diaphragmatic hernia

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Congenital diaphragmatic hernia often presents with neonatal respiratory distress, bowel sounds in the chest, and air-fluid levels on X-ray. The most important prognostic factor is the degree of pulmonary hypoplasia and pulmonary hypertension.

questions.text: Identify the condition in the image.
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Omphalocele

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Omphalocele is a congenital defect where abdominal organs herniate through the umbilical region, covered by a membrane. The presence of a covering membrane distinguishes it from other abdominal wall defects.

questions.text: Which of the following is considered a “sure sign” of wound dehiscence in a post-operative patient?

options.label: D
options.text: Widening of the abdominal scar with palpable edges

questions.correct_answer: C. Serosanguinous drainage from the wound
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Serosanguinous drainage from the wound

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Serosanguinous drainage from a post-operative wound is a critical early warning sign of wound dehiscence and should prompt immediate evaluation and intervention.

questions.text: A 55-year-old male patient who is a known case of alcohol induced liver disease presented in OPD with pain in abdomen and unintentional weight loss. AST/ALT are normal, alpha fetoprotein is raised. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Hepatocellular carcinoma

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ In patients with chronic liver disease or cirrhosis, new symptoms such as weight loss, abdominal pain, or elevated AFP should raise suspicion for hepatocellular carcinoma.

questions.text: A patient presents in emergency department with sudden hematemesis. He has been taking aspirin for his arthritis and drinks alcohol occasionally. He gives a history of occasional abdominal pain. On examination, there is no abdominal mass or tenderness. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Peptic ulcer

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Peptic ulcer disease should be suspected in patients with hematemesis, a history of NSAID use, and occasional abdominal pain, particularly when there is no evidence of liver disease or varices.

questions.text: Identify the condition according to given image.
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Trophic ulcer

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Trophic ulcers are commonly seen in neuropathic conditions like diabetes and are typically found on weight-bearing areas of the foot. They are deep, often painless, and surrounded by callosity.

questions.text: A 28-year-old male patient presents in surgery OPD with midline swelling in the neck. The swelling moves with deglutition and protrusion of the tongue. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Thyroglossal cyst

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Thyroglossal duct cysts are characterized by a midline neck swelling that moves with tongue protrusion and swallowing, requiring the Sistrunk procedure for definitive management.

questions.text: A 25-year-old male presented to the emergency department after a motor vehicle accident. He was the driver of the car, and upon impact, he had hit his abdomen against the steering wheel. Upon examination, the patient was conscious but complained of severe abdominal pain and tenderness upon palpation. Further evaluation revealed the evisceration of omentum, which was protruding through a laceration in the abdominal wall. What would be the best management of the same?
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Emergency laparotomy

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Visible evisceration in penetrating trauma mandates immediate laparotomy, bypassing further imaging.

questions.text: A 34-year-old female patient presents with lower abdominal pain, frequent urination, and signs of dehydration. Physical examination reveals abdominal tenderness, and urine analysis indicates sterile pyuria. An image is provided. What is the most likely condition?
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) TB kidney

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Unilateral kidney calcification with sterile pyuria and abdominal tenderness is indicative of renal tuberculosis, often termed "cement kidney."

questions.text: Which of the following is not true about nephroblastoma?

options.label: C
options.text: Treatment is by chemotherapy and surgery

options.label: D
options.text: It is the most common intra-abdominal malignancy in children

questions.correct_answer: D. It is the most common intra-abdominal malignancy in children
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) It is the most common intra-abdominal malignancy in children

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Nephroblastoma is a common pediatric kidney cancer, other intra-abdominal malignancies, like neuroblastoma, are more common in children.

questions.text: Identify the condition that does not lead to bilateral hydronephrosis?
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Retrocaval ureter

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Retrocaval ureter leads to unilateral hydronephrosis, while conditions like urethral stricture, phimosis, and posterior urethral valve can cause bilateral hydronephrosis due to distal urinary obstruction.
  • ➤ Retrocaval ureter

questions.text: A female presented with pain and redness of the left breast. She is lactating for the last 3 months. On examination, local temperature is raised and cracked nipple is noted. Ultrasound of breast was suggestive of significant liquid collection of about 100 cc. What should be the next line of management?
questions.explanation:
Ans.

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ For a breast abscess with a significant fluid collection (e.g., 100 cc), suction catheter insertion is the preferred treatment to ensure adequate drainage and resolution of the infection.

questions.text: Identify the pathology in the newborn baby as shown in the image?
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Anorectal malformation

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ An invertogram X-ray is used specifically to diagnose anorectal malformations in newborns, helping to assess the location and presence of the rectal pouch.Bottom of Form

questions.text: A patient has undergone surgery as shown in the image below. After this surgery, the patient presents with pallor, dizziness and sweating whenever he has a large meal. What could this be?
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Dumping syndrome

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Dumping syndrome is a postoperative complication associated with gastric surgeries where rapid gastric emptying leads to symptoms like dizziness, sweating, and pallor, especially after large meals.

questions.text: What is the diagnosis and treatment for the pathology as shown in the given image?
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Dermoid cyst: Excision

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ For cysts, such as dermoid cysts, the standard treatment is excision , not incision and drainage. Incision and drainage is used for abscesses, while cysts should be fully removed to prevent recurrence.
  • ➤ excision

questions.text: A lady was incidentally diagnosed with a 1.5 cm solid mass in her Gall Bladder on USG which is immobile and it is diagnosed as a gall bladder polyp. She is asymptomatic. What is the next step in the management?

options.label: A
options.text: Reassure the patient and follow up

questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Laparoscopic Cholecystectomy

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Gall bladder polyps greater than 1 cm should generally be managed with cholecystectomy due to the elevated risk of malignancy.
  • ➤ cholecystectomy

questions.text: A patient was operated on for benign prostatic hyperplasia. On evaluation, incidentally, cancer of the Prostate was detected and on further workup was found to have metastasis. Which of the following drug is used for treatment?
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Bicalutamide

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Androgen deprivation therapy (ADT) is the mainstay for metastatic prostate cancer, and bicalutamide is an androgen receptor blocker used in combination with GnRH analogs to inhibit androgen effects and manage metastatic disease.
  • ➤ Androgen deprivation therapy (ADT)
  • ➤ bicalutamide

questions.text: A new born presents with congenital anomaly of cleft lip. Which is the embryological development defect?

options.label: B
options.text: Non fusion of medial nasal process & maxillary process

options.label: C
options.text: Non fusion of lateral nasal process & maxillary process

options.label: D
options.text: Separation of nasal septum & vomer from palatine process

questions.correct_answer: B. Non fusion of medial nasal process & maxillary process
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Non fusion of medial nasal process & maxillary process

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Cleft lip results from the non-fusion of the medial nasal and maxillary processes during embryological development.
  • ➤ non-fusion of the medial nasal and maxillary processes

questions.text: Barium swallow image demonstrated below indicates:
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Zenker’s diverticulum

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Zenker’s diverticulum is best identified on a lateral barium swallow image as a posterior outpouching in the cervical esophagus, unlike other esophageal conditions that primarily affect the thoracic region.

questions.text: In an asymptomatic patient, on routine screening a small mass was detected in the rectum which looked like a suspected neoplasm. What is the next step in the management?
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Sigmoidoscopy with lesion biopsy

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The first step in managing a suspected neoplastic mass in the rectum is sigmoidoscopy with biopsy to confirm the diagnosis before proceeding with staging and treatment planning.
  • ➤ sigmoidoscopy with biopsy

questions.text: A patient came with the pain in right hypochondrium. Blood investigation shows AST-22 IU/l and ALT-27 IU/ L, serum direct bilirubin levels -6mg% and ALP-400 mg % What should be the next investigation in this patient?

options.label: C
options.text: Hepatitis A and Hepatitis E markers

questions.explanation:
Ans. A) USG abdomen

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ In cases of suspected obstructive jaundice, the first-line investigation is an ultrasound of the abdomen to evaluate the liver, gallbladder, and bile ducts before considering further imaging modalities.
  • ➤ first-line investigation is an ultrasound of the abdomen

questions.text: Identify the procedure leading to the complication shown in image:
questions.explanation:
Ans.  A) ESWL

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Steinstrasse is a complication of ESWL and occurs when stone fragments obstruct the ureter, causing pain and possible hematuria.
  • ➤ ESWL

questions.text: According to Wallace’s rule, genitalia represent what % of TBSA?
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) 1

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ According to Wallace's Rule of Nines , the genitalia represent 1% of the Total Body Surface Area (TBSA) in burn assessments.
  • ➤ Wallace's Rule of Nines
  • ➤ 1% of the Total Body Surface Area (TBSA)

questions.text: What is the pressure in the wound healing procedure shown in the image below:
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Minus (-) 125 mm of Hg

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Negative Pressure Wound Therapy (NPWT) involves applying a negative pressure of minus 125 mm Hg to facilitate wound healing in chronic and non-healing wounds.
  • ➤ Negative Pressure Wound Therapy (NPWT)
  • ➤ minus 125 mm Hg

questions.text: Most accurate investigation for local staging of CA Prostate is:
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) MRI

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ MRI is the most accurate modality for local staging of prostate cancer, and it is similarly valuable for staging other pelvic malignancies.
  • ➤ MRI

questions.text: A 56 years old male presents to the emergency with abdominal pain and an episode of binge drinking in shock with a BP of 70/50 mm Hg and HR of 115/min. The oxygen saturation of the patient is 89%. Serum creatinine level was 2.4 mg/dL. What is the likely diagnosis based on the CT image shown below?
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Severe acute pancreatitis

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Severe acute pancreatitis is defined by the presence of systemic organ failure and is commonly associated with necrosis seen on imaging. A history of binge drinking and clinical indicators of organ failure strongly point to this diagnosis.

questions.text: 35-year-old healthy male is presented with a gunshot wound to right upper thigh region. On examination, patient was hemodynamically stable but had no palpable lower extremity pulses on the injured side. On exploration - superficial femoral artery was transected. Which of the following is the suture material to be used for vascular repair?
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Polypropylene

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ For vascular repairs, polypropylene is the preferred non-absorbable suture material due to its durability and minimal tissue reactivity, making it ideal for maintaining vessel integrity.
  • ➤ polypropylene

questions.text: The procedure shown in the image is used in the treatment of lower limb varicose veins. What is the procedure and what type of anesthesia is commonly used for this procedure?
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) EVLA-local tumescent anesthesia

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Endovenous Laser Ablation (EVLA) for varicose veins is typically performed under local tumescent anesthesia for patient comfort and effective pain management.
  • ➤ Endovenous Laser Ablation (EVLA)
  • ➤ local tumescent anesthesia

questions.text: Identify the surgical position shown in the image?
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Reverse Trendelenburg position

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The Reverse Trendelenburg position is characterized by elevating the head and lowering the feet, which is useful for certain abdominal and thoracic surgeries.
  • ➤ Reverse Trendelenburg position

questions.text: At what angle should the skin be pierced with the needle, while suturing the skin using interrupted sutures?
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) 90 degrees

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The correct angle for inserting the needle in skin suturing is 90 degrees , which ensures optimal tissue approximation and reduces the risk of wound dehiscence.
  • ➤ 90 degrees

questions.text: Identify the correct diagnosis on the basis of given image of newborn baby?
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Exstrophy bladder

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Bladder exstrophy is a congenital condition where the bladder is exposed through an abdominal wall defect and requires surgical intervention to close the defect and protect the bladder tissue.
  • ➤ Bladder exstrophy

questions.text: Identify the finding on endoscopy in the image shown:
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Gastric Antral Vascular Ectasia

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Gastric Antral Vascular Ectasia (GAVE) , or "watermelon stomach," is recognized by its distinctive longitudinal red stripes in the antrum . It is associated with chronic bleeding and may lead to anemia.
  • ➤ Gastric Antral Vascular Ectasia (GAVE)
  • ➤ longitudinal red stripes in the antrum

questions.text: Most common ectopic tissue found in Meckel’s diverticulum is/are? Gastric Colonic Pancreatic Thyroid
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) 1 and 3

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The most common types of ectopic tissue in Meckel’s diverticulum are gastric (most common) and pancreatic.

questions.text: On raising the hands above the head, the given test is seen to be positive. Which of these is true about the swelling?

options.label: A
options.text: The swelling causes compression of IVC

options.label: B
options.text: The swelling should always be excised

options.label: C
options.text: The swelling moves up with deglutition

options.label: D
options.text: The swelling often receives blood supply from superior thyroid artery

questions.correct_answer: C. The swelling moves up with deglutition
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) The swelling moves up with deglutition

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ A retrosternal goiter, which can compress the SVC, moves up with deglutition and typically receives blood supply from the inferior thyroid artery. Excision is only indicated in symptomatic cases or if there is a risk of malignancy.

questions.text: A 45-year-old lady presents to the emergency department with severe abdominal pain. An abdominal ultrasound reveals the presence of multiple gallstones with no evidence of wall thickening. The bile duct (BD) diameter is measured as 12 mm (dilated), and serum bilirubin levels are mildly elevated at 0.8. The patient's alkaline phosphatase levels are significantly elevated at 680, and the gamma-glutamyl transferase (GGT) levels are raised by 5 times. What is the next best step in the management of this patient?
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) MRCP

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ In cases of suspected obstructive jaundice with a dilated bile duct, MRCP is the investigation of choice to confirm CBD stones or other causes of obstruction before therapeutic intervention with ERCP.

questions.text: According to European hernia society classification (EHS), hernia labelled as PL2 implies?

options.label: A
options.text: Primary direct with defect of 2 cm

options.label: B
options.text: Primary indirect with defect of 2 cm

options.label: C
options.text: Primary direct with defect of 2 finger breadth

options.label: D
options.text: Primary indirect with defect of 2 finger breadth

questions.correct_answer: D. Primary indirect with defect of 2 finger breadth
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Primary indirect with defect of 2 finger breadth

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ European Hernia Society (EHS) classification system , "PL2" denotes a primary lateral (indirect) hernia with a defect size of 2 finger breadths .
  • ➤ European Hernia Society (EHS) classification system
  • ➤ primary lateral (indirect) hernia with a defect size of 2 finger breadths
  • ➤ P= Primary L= Lateral= Indirect M= Medial= direct Defect size in finger breadth.
  • ➤ P= Primary
  • ➤ L= Lateral= Indirect
  • ➤ M= Medial= direct
  • ➤ Defect size in finger breadth.

questions.text: This instrument is commonly used for:

options.label: C
options.text: Retracting superficial layers like skin and subcutaneous tissue

questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Retracting viscera like liver

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The Deaver retractor is commonly used for retracting soft tissues and internal organs, particularly the liver, in abdominal surgeries.

questions.text: The following procedure is performed for the management of:
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Distal cholangiocarcinoma

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The Whipple procedure is primarily used for malignancies near the head of the pancreas, including distal cholangiocarcinoma and periampullary carcinoma, involving the removal and reconstruction of pancreatic, bile duct, and gastric structures.

questions.text: A 7-year-old girl from Maharashtra presented with pain in the right upper abdomen, lump in the abdomen. Investigation revealed conjugated hyper-bilirubinemia. USG abdomen showed dilated CBD of 6 mm. What will be your next investigation and expected finding?
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) MRCP, choledochal cyst

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ In a young child, especially of Asian descent, with abdominal pain, a palpable lump, conjugated hyperbilirubinemia, and a dilated CBD, MRCP is the next best step to confirm a diagnosis of choledochal cyst.

questions.text: A 40-year-old male underwent surgery for rectal prolapse, and a image was obtained. Can you identify the procedure that was most likely performed on the patient from the given image?
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Well's procedure

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Mesh rectopexy, as seen in Well’s procedure, is an abdominal approach for rectal prolapse where a mesh is used to stabilize the rectum, reducing recurrence.

questions.text: A patient came to the OPD with a history of burn wound on the lower limb. His wound is given in the picture. What is the probable diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Squamous cell Ca

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ A chronic non-healing ulcer in a burn scar, especially one with indurated or irregular edges, should raise suspicion of Marjolin ulcer, a form of squamous cell carcinoma with low metastasis potential due to prior vascular damage.

questions.text: What is the management for a patient with a road traffic accident who presents with hemothorax, evidenced by 1600 ml of blood loss via a chest tube in 1 hour?
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Thoracotomy

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ For traumatic hemothorax with high-volume blood loss (>1500 ml initially or >200-250 ml per hour for 3 hours), immediate thoracotomy is indicated to control the source of bleeding and stabilize the patient.

questions.text: A 40-year-old female presented to the dermatologist with a small lesion on her right nasolabial fold. Upon examination, the dermatologist noted a 0.4-cm nodule with ill-defined borders. The nodule was located on the upper forehead, just above the eyebrows. It was excised and a pathological examination was done. The image is given below. What is the diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Basal cell carcinoma

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Basal Cell Carcinoma (BCC) is the most common type of skin cancer and is identified histologically by peripheral palisading and beaded or rolled-out edges. BCC usually spreads locally and is treated effectively with Mohs micrographic surgery.
  • ➤ Basal Cell Carcinoma (BCC) is the most common type of skin cancer and is identified histologically by peripheral palisading and beaded or rolled-out edges.
  • ➤ BCC usually spreads locally and is treated effectively with Mohs micrographic surgery.

questions.text: Which of the following incisions for appendectomy is likely to result in ilio-hypogastric nerve injury?
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Rutherford Morrison

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The Rutherford Morrison incision is a muscle-cutting approach that increases the risk of iliohypogastric nerve injury due to direct muscle division, potentially leading to sensory or motor deficits in the lower abdomen.

questions.text: A young male presented with significant dragging sensation in the scrotum. On examination a bag of worm feel was noted in the left side of the scrotum. However, testes were normal. What is the first-line treatment?

options.label: A
options.text: Ligation of testicular vein at deep ring

questions.correct_answer: B. Percutaneous embolization of testicular vein
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Percutaneous embolization of testicular vein

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The first-line treatment for varicocele is percutaneous embolization of the testicular vein, which alleviates symptoms and prevents complications such as infertility.

questions.text: A 30-year-old housewife accidentally spilled hot tea all over herself at a kitty party. She gets this lesion on her right hand which is very painful and erythematous. Which parts of the skin are affected in this scenario?
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Epidermis + superficial dermis

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Superficial partial-thickness (second-degree) burns involve the epidermis and superficial dermis , presenting with erythema, blistering, and significant pain.
  • ➤ Superficial partial-thickness (second-degree) burns
  • ➤ epidermis and superficial dermis

questions.text: What is not true regarding renal stones?

options.label: A
options.text: Most common type of stone is struvite

options.label: B
options.text: Small stones can be managed conservatively with pharmacotherapy

options.label: C
options.text: Soft stones can be removed by ESWL

options.label: D
options.text: Envelope shaped crystals are seen in calcium oxalate dihydrate stones

questions.correct_answer: A. Most common type of stone is struvite
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Most common type of stone is struvite

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The most common type of renal stone is calcium oxalate, not struvite. Envelope-shaped crystals are characteristic of calcium oxalate dihydrate stones.

questions.text: Which of these is the most common etiology for the given finding?
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Filariasis

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The most common cause of lymphedema in endemic areas is filariasis , leading to chronic swelling and characteristic physical findings like squared toes and non-pitting edema .
  • ➤ lymphedema in endemic areas
  • ➤ filariasis
  • ➤ squared toes and non-pitting edema
